newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russian MinFins up but bond freezing worries stay.
newsitem.headline: Russian MinFins up but bond freezing worries stay.

text.p: Prices of Russian MinFin bonds firmed on Thursday, helped by a denial more bonds could be frozen, peace talks in Chechnya, President Boris Yeltsin's appearance on television and payment of a new tranche of the International Monetary Fund loan.
"The market is firmer today largely because participants are more relaxed about the rumours on new frozen bonds," a Moscow Narodny Bank dealer said.

MinFin bond prices fell on Wednesday mainly on rumours some banks had had some of their bonds frozen. But a finance ministry official who declined to be named told Reuters that no new bonds had been frozen.
"The day is less nervous, but yesterday's rumours are still keeping many Russian and some London operators out of the market as such things can outweigh any good news," a Russian bank dealer said.
MinFin bond prices were hit in June when the finance ministry said it would not service stolen bonds totalling $24.22 million, part of which were stolen in breakaway Chechnya.
The dealer also noted buying by a London operator that helped boost prices.

"The fact that Yeltsin is back in Moscow... and hopes that the conflict in Chechnya is being resolved are also positive for the market. The IMF tranche also has a good effect," the Moscow Narodny Bank dealer said.
On Wednesday, the IMF released the July tranche of a $10 billion loan, which had been withheld because of Fund concerns about the impact on fiscal policy of poor tax collection.
